H0.text: Pulsars are very bright, seemingly very distant objects that astronomers have concluded are distant galaxies with giant black holes at their center.

H1.text: Quasars are very bright objects that appear to be very far away, and astronomers have concluded that they are distant galaxies with giant black holes at their centers.

H2.text: Supernovas are the distant galaxies with giant black holes at their center that astronomers have been studying, noting that they are very bright and appear very far away.

H3.text: Binary stars are the very bright objects astronomers have studied that appear to be very far away, and they have concluded that these objects are distant galaxies with giant black holes at their centers.

A4.text: The power of quasars originates from supermassive black holes that are believed to exist at the core of most galaxies.

A5.text: High-resolution images of quasars, particularly from the Hubble Space Telescope, have shown that quasars occur in the centers of galaxies, and that some host galaxies are strongly interacting or merging galaxies.
